questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after a sudden onset of fever, vomiting, and irritability. The child’s parents report that he had a productive cough and runny nose for the past few days, which seemed to improve before the acute deterioration. On examination, the child appears lethargic and is febrile (39°C or 102.2°F). There is hypotension (blood pressure 85/50 mmHg), and he is tachycardic (heart rate 120 bpm). Physical examination reveals diffuse petechial rashes on the lower extremities and trunk. Laboratory findings show: WBC count : 18,000/µL (elevated) Blood cultures :  Which laboratory finding is most commonly associated with Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome?

A 42-year-old woman presents to your clinic with complaints of progressive fatigue, headaches, and increased skin pigmentation over the past few months. She has a history of Cushing's disease, which was diagnosed 4 years ago, and underwent a bilateral adrenalectomy. Upon physical examination, she appears lethargic and has a noticeable darkening of the skin around her neck and on her palms. She also mentions new-onset visual disturbances. Which of the following is false about her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Visual disturbances are due to Nerve compression

questions.explanation:
Definition

Nelson's syndrome is a condition that typically occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy for the treatment of Cushing's disease (pituitary-dependent Cushing’s syndrome). The removal of the adrenal glands leads to a lack of negative feedback on the pituitary, resulting in increased secretion of ACTH. Over time, the pituitary gland may develop a pituitary adenoma (or enlargement of an existing adenoma), which secretes ACTH in excess. (Option C and D ruled out)

Prevention

Prophylactic radiation therapy may be indicated to prevent the development of Nelson’s syndrome after adrenalectomy

Clinical features

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Progressive visual loss in cases of large tumors(Option A ruled out)
  • Headache
  • Weakness and fatigue
  • Inhibition of the release of other pituitary hormones

Evaluation

  • Fasting Plasma ACTH Levels:
    • Very high levels. (Option B)
    • Diagnosis confirmed by an ACTH increase >30% of the initial result on three consecutive samples after bilateral adrenalectomy.
  • Decreased levels of anterior pituitary hormones.
  • Brain MRI shows pituitary tumors or enlargement of existing tumors.
  • Screening:
    • Regular screening with fasting plasma ACTH levels and brain MRI in patients after bilateral adrenalectomy.

Management

  • Surgical Removal of the Tumor
  • Radiotherapy / Radiosurgery
  • Medical Treatment
  • Hormonal Replacement Therapy

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a confirmed diagnosis of Cushing's disease presents with symptoms of central obesity, hypertension, and muscle weakness. Imaging reveals a 5 mm pituitary adenoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment approach for this patient?

A 45-year-old woman presents with weight gain, fatigue and difficulty climbing stairs. On physical examination, she has central obesity, a rounded face and broad purple striae on her abdomen. The internist suspects the case to be Cushing's syndrome. What is the most likely additional clinical feature associated with this patient?

A 52-year-old man presents with symptoms of weight gain, central obesity, hypertension, purple abdominal striae, hyperpigmentation of knuckles, and muscle weakness. Imaging reveals a lung mass. Which of the following is the most likely cause in this patient?

A patient with a history of neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) presents with symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, including frequent episodes of watery diarrhea and flushing. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment to control these symptoms, particularly diarrhea?
questions.explanation:
Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Carcinoid syndrome is caused by hormone secretion (mainly serotonin) from neuroendocrine tumors (NETs).
  • Commonly arises from NETs in the small intestine or appendix.
  • The syndrome typically occurs when the tumor has metastasized to the liver or retroperitoneum, allowing the hormones to enter systemic circulation.
  • Histamine and tachykinins (e.g., substance P) may also contribute to the syndrome.

Common Symptoms
  • Flushing: Sudden onset of an intense red or purplish color, especially on the upper body, neck, and face, often with a sensation of warmth.
  • Diarrhea: Frequent watery stools, often over 10 times/day, significantly impacting daily life.

Less Common Symptoms
  • Wheezing or asthma-like symptoms
  • Impaired cognitive function in advanced cases
  • Pellagra-like skin lesions due to niacin deficiency (from tryptophan being used to produce serotonin instead of niacin).

Management
  • Somatostatin analogues: Mainstay treatment that mimics somatostatin, which inhibits hormone secretion (e.g., serotonin).
    • Most NETs (around 90%) have somatostatin receptors and respond to these analogues.
  • Telotristat ethyl: Blocks serotonin production; used as adjunctive therapy for patients who don't fully respond to somatostatin analogues. (Option B ruled out)
  • Surgery: Considered for localized tumors but often not possible in patients with metastatic disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency room with severe headaches, palpitations and profuse sweating. His blood pressure is measured at 180/110 mmHg. Initial biochemical testing shows elevated plasma metanephrines and catecholamines. An MRI reveals a mass in the extra-adrenal retroperitoneal area. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy to control his blood pressure before surgery?
questions.explanation:
Paraganglioma
  • Catecholamine-producing tumors from sympathetic or parasympathetic nervous systems.
  • Can be sporadic or hereditary (25-33% linked to MEN 2, VHL syndromes).
  • Location: Skull base and neck.
  • Called pheochromocytomas if present in retroperitoneal, pelvic, and thoracic regions.

Clinical Features
  • Referred to as "the great masquerader" due to variable presentation.
  • Common symptoms: Headaches, sweating, palpitations, tachycardia, hypertension, anxiety, panic attacks.
  • Hypertension is the main sign (can lead to heart failure, pulmonary edema, arrhythmias, and intracranial hemorrhage).
  • Rarely, hypotension may occur if epinephrine predominates.

Diagnosis
  • Biochemical testing: Plasma or urine-fractionated catecholamines/ metanephrines (most sensitive).
  • Imaging: CT, MRI (T2-weighted, gadolinium for extra-adrenal), PET (68Ga-DOTATATE PET) for tumor localization.
  • Genetic screening is advised for young-onset, multifocal, extra-adrenal, or metastatic tumors.

Treatment
  • Surgical removal: Adrenalectomy (partial or total); preserve adrenal cortex to avoid Addison’s disease.
  • Medical management: Preoperative blood pressure control below 160/90 mmHg is essential.
    • Alpha-adrenergic blockers: Phenoxybenzamine (non-selective, preferred) to prevent hypertensive crises; prazosin/ phentolamine for paroxysms; liberal salt and hydration to avoid orthostasis.
    • Beta blockers: Added after alpha blockade.
    • Other antihypertensives: Calcium channel blockers and ACE inhibitors.
    • Intraoperative BP control with nitroprusside if necessary.
  • Metastatic Paraganglioma:
    • Treatment options include surgery, alpha-blockers, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and nuclear medicine therapy (e.g., 131I-MIBG).

questions.text: What is the most sensitive diagnostic test for detecting pheochromocytoma?

A 45-year-old woman presents with episodic headaches, sweating, and palpitations. She has been experiencing high blood pressure that is difficult to control despite multiple antihypertensive medications. On physical examination, her heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg.Laboratory studies reveal elevated plasma-free metanephrines. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Etiopathogenesis
  • These tumors can be benign or malignant and are frequently associated with familial syndromes like neurofibromatosis type 1, multiple endocrine neoplasia type II, and Von-Hippel Lindau disease.
  • Catecholamines are produced in the chromaffin cells starting with the rate-limiting step of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), regulating the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).
  • Pheochromocytomas release these catecholamines in various patterns ranging from paroxysmal, continuous, and mixed patterns.

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad: Episode of palpitation + Headache +Profuse sweating
  • Dominant sign is Hypertension- 40% have sustained hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Plasma tests

  • Catecholamines
  • Free metanephrines

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumor.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers(phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy
  • Open adrenalectomy

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

questions.text: Which of the following genetic conditions are associated with pheochromocytomas?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Epidemiology
  • Estimated to occur in 2 to 8 of 1 million persons per year.
  • The mean age at diagnosis is 40 years, although the tumours can occur from early childhood until late in life.
  • The classic ‘rule of tens’ is 10% bilateral, 10% extra-adrenal (Paragangliomas), and 10% metastatic. It is not used nowadays.

Etiopathogenesis
  • These tumors can be benign or malignant and are frequently associated with familial syndromes like
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1,
    • multiple endocrine neoplasia type II, and
    • Von-Hippel Lindau disease.
  • Catecholamines are produced in the chromaffin cells starting with the rate-limiting step of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), regulating the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).
  • Pheochromocytomas release these catecholamines in various patterns ranging from paroxysmal, continuous, and mixed patterns. Norepinephrine is released continuously and can result in persistent hypertension, while epinephrine is released in a paroxysmal pattern resulting in tachyarrhythmias.
    • Ryanodine-2 receptors (RyR2).
    • Beta-2 adrenoceptors
    • Alpha(1)-adrenoreceptors

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • Dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumor.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning    

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection.
  • Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers(phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • Open adrenalectomy

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.
  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with persistent hypertension, weight gain, and muscle weakness. Her laboratory results reveal elevated cortisol levels and suppressed ACTH. Imaging studies show an adrenal mass, as shown below. Which of the following layers of the adrenal gland is most likely responsible for the hormone excess in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Layers of Adrenal Gland

Zona glomerulosa (Option A ruled out)
  • The outermost layer of the cortex.
  • It secretes aldosterone, a mineralocorticoid that regulates sodium retention and potassium and proton excretion.
  • Aldosterone production is mainly stimulated by angiotensin II, which is part of the renin-angiotensin system- This is not under the control of ACTH.

Zona fasciculata (Option B)
  • The middle layer of the cortex secretes cortisol.
  • It also secretes adrenal androgens.
  • An adrenal mass in this layer could cause increased cortisol production, resulting in symptoms such as hypertension, muscle weakness, and weight gain, consistent with Cushing’s syndrome.

Zona reticularis (Option C ruled out)
  • Innermost layer of the cortex.
  • It secretes cortisol and adrenal androgens.
  • The zona fasciculata and zona reticularis function together as one unit in response to the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).
  • An adrenal mass in this layer results in excess androgens resulting in virilization and other symptoms.

Adrenal Medulla (Option D ruled out)
  • Part of the sympathetic nervous system
  • Secretes catecholamines (adrenaline and noradrenaline) into capillaries
  • Symptoms related to catecholamine excess include palpitations and tachycardia.

Etiology

    • Polyglandular syndromes
  • Tuberculosis: M/C/C in India
  • Histoplasmosis
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Metastatic carcinoma

Clinical Features

  • Glucocorticoid insufficiency (Option A ruled out):

questions.text: Which part of the kidney is affected in Gordon syndrome?

options.label: C
options.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

options.label: D
options.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.explanation:
Inheritance

Autosomal dominant (mostly)

Pathogenesis

Mutations in the WNK1, WNK4, CUL3, or KLHL3 genes result in abnormalities in serine/threonine kinases that dysregulate the thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride cotransporter (NCC) in the distal nephron (Option A). This leads to increased sodium and chloride reabsorption, causing extracellular volume expansion and subsequent hypertension.

Clinical Presentation

Non-specific symptoms like muscle weakness, fatigue, hypertension (not always)

Laboratory Findings
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
  • Hypercalciuria
  • Low or low-normal plasma renin activity
  • Low serum aldosterone levels (relative to hyperkalemia)
  • Normal kidney function/normal glomerular filtration

Management
  • Correction of electrolyte abnormalities
  • Salt restriction
  • Thiazide diuretics

questions.text: All of the following are clinical manifestations of Liddle’s syndrome except?
questions.explanation:
Definition

An autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by hypertension with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hyporeninemia, and suppressed aldosterone secretion

Pathophysiology

Mutations in SCNN1A, SCNN1B, and SCNN1G genes → α, β, and γ subunits of ENaC (Epithelial Sodium Channel) altered → Increased Epithelial Sodium Channel activity→Elevated sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron → Sodium retention

Clinical features

- Early-onset hypertension (as early as 2 years of age) (Option C ruled out)

- Hypokalemia (Option A ruled out) and metabolic alkalosis

- Suppressed plasma renin (Option B ruled out) and aldosterone levels (Option D)

- Fatigue, muscle weakness, dizziness, and vision changes

Management

- Potassium-sparing diuretics: Amiloride or Triamterene

- Salt restriction
